instruction:
I'm writing a NeurIPS paper about a new model architecture for processing and generating long texts. Here are some facts about the paper:
* The main trick is to replace some of the attention heads with an exponential moving average, where the decay rate is learned for each head. We call this architecture ExeMA.
* On language modeling, the perplexity difference between our model and a vanilla transformer is negligible, but that's because next-token prediction is almost always a local task, so perplexity won't be sensitive enough to detect any improvements in long-range understanding.
* However, on the SCROLLS benchmark, our model improves by 10% over the baseline.
* We also have a new metric for measuring coherence in generated text (CoGnaTe), where our model generates text that is 43% more coherent than the baseline.
Help me write the paper's introduction.
output: TL;DR: I'm writing a NeurIPS paper about a new model architecture for processing and generating long texts. The model improves by 10% on a benchmark and generates text that is 43% more coherent than the baseline. Help me write the paper's introduction.

instruction: I'm interested in renting a house in a posh neighborhood in the US. Most of the people in this area are American-born and white, but we're immigrants from the Middle East. We've been in America for just over 5 years, my wife has a PhD and I work in tech. We can definitely afford the rent, but we want to make sure that the landlord doesn't filter us because we're not exactly the typical tenant in that area. Can you help me write a cover letter for our rent application?
output:
Hi [Landlord],
We’re writing to express our interest in renting a house in your neighborhood. We’re aware that the area is popular with families and we think it will be a great place to raise our children. We also understand that the neighborhood is primarily inhabited by American-born and white people, but our family comes from the Middle East and we speak Arabic at home.
We believe that our professional backgrounds – my wife is a PhD and I work in tech – and our willingness to be active members of the community will make us good tenants. We can definitely afford the rent, and we’d love to become part of the local community.

instruction: What is the most efficient way to get the number of rows in a table with psycog2?

query = "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM table"

What is the most efficient way to get the number of rows in a table with psycog2?

instruction: What does Bing need to do to beat Google?
output:
Terry Myerson, Microsoft's executive vice president of the Windows and Devices Group, just about summed up the company's strategy for the next version of its smartphone OS during an event in San Francisco on Wednesday.
In many ways, it's a continuation of the existing Microsoft strategy for mobile -- one that emphasizes enterprise appeal above all else -- but there are a few notable changes as well. The update, known as Windows 10 Mobile, will be available for free to existing Windows Phone 8.1 handsets this fall, and it will also run on new devices from partners like Alcatel, HP, and Lenovo.
Microsoft is joining the likes of BlackBerry and Palm by embracing the concept of a single OS shared across multiple device types. In this case, the end goal is to bring together Windows 10 apps onto phones, tablets, and even PCs. While you won't find touch-friendly versions of full desktop apps on your phone anytime soon, Microsoft has already announced that Office Mobile apps like Word, Excel, and PowerPoint will be universal across all Windows 10 devices.
Just as importantly, the OS will support Continuum, which lets you connect your phone to a mouse and keyboard and use it as a desktop computer. It will also support universal tasks like taking a phone call on your PC or resuming a video on your TV that you started on your phone.
And yes, Microsoft did confirm that Windows 10 Mobile will run on ARM chips, too, though it didn't offer any specific hardware partners yet.
Windows 10 Mobile will support all the same key enterprise features as the PC and tablet editions of Windows 10, including support for enterprise mobile management (EMM) tools (including tools like Samsung's Knox), secure boot,

instruction: What can I do for 6 days in the South of France

I am traveling to the South of France with my husband for 6 days.
What are the must-see places and things to do here? We will be staying in Aix-en-Provence, but would like to spend one day exploring other nearby destinations.
south-of-france aix-en-provence
I'm voting to close this question as off-topic because it's about making recommendations, not about a specific travel problem. – JoErNanO Oct 23 '15 at 17:11
protected by Community♦ Oct 23 '15 at 18:04
When I see "suggestion" questions closed, I think that all those answers may be useful. This is not exactly a "best restaurant in NYC" kind of question. It's not really subjective either. Questions like this can be a good way to get ideas for a trip. – John Zwinck Oct 23 '15 at 19:39
@JohnZwinck: While I agree with you in general, I think that this question is actually quite bad. The answer would really depend on what the OP would like to see. There are many beautiful places in Provence, and it's not really possible to write an objective answer that would be of any help to future visitors. So while I'm voting to reopen (since the question was closed due to community votes only), I'm also going to edit the question to remove the "suggestion" tag. – Relaxed Oct 24 '15 at 12:21
Your question is asking for recommendations based on your location and time constraints. As such, it's off topic here on Travel.SE. Consider posting on a site like Quora or Yahoo! Answers instead.

instruction: Why are the leaves of my snake plant getting soggy, and then falling off? I recently repotted it. I only water it once a month.
output:
your plant is suffering from too much moisture. The leaves are quite thin and they cannot hold a lot of water. When the soil is too wet, the leaves start to rot and eventually fall off. Therefore, you have to make sure that the soil dry well between watering, and do not let it sit in a saucer full of water after watering.
Instead, water the plant at the soil level to avoid rotting the thin leaves of your snake plant.

instruction:
Can you summarize this passage into bullet points?

Gradually slowing job gains and a growing labor force in March delivered welcome news to President Biden, nearly a year after he declared that the job market needed to cool significantly to tame high prices. The details of the report are encouraging for a president whose economic goal is to move from rapid job gains — and high inflation — to what Mr. Biden has called “stable, steady growth.” Job creation slowed to 236,000 for the month, closing in on the level Mr. Biden said last year would be necessary to stabilize the economy and prices. More Americans joined the labor force, and wage gains fell slightly. Those developments should help to further cool inflation. But the report also underscored the political and economic tensions for the president as he seeks to sell Americans on his economic stewardship ahead of an expected announcement this spring that he will seek re-election.
output:
236k job gains, 100k less than expected.
Growing labor force - more people looking for jobs.
Wage gains fell slightly.
Job creation slowed to 236k, closing in on the level Biden said last year would be necessary to stabilize the economy and prices.
More Americans joined the labor force, potentially increasing competition for jobs.

instruction: I live in the Bay Area and I've had it with PG&E. Devise a plan to start a competing energy company to put them out of business.
output:
So far nobody has come up with a compelling plan to start a competing energy company.  Every attempt I've seen so far has assumed that the government will allow them to somehow do this without competition from PG&E.  I don't see how that can happen.
At the very least, you need to get past all the regulatory barriers erected by PG&E.  If you could crack those, then you would be in business.  The most efficient way to do this is to buy out a local co-op and threaten to shut down service unless they are allowed to join your new co-op.
Here are some of the major regulatory barriers:
1. You can't just build a power line and connect it to the grid.  PG&E controls where the lines go and who pays for what.  It costs about $20M/mile to string a new line.  They have thousands of miles of line.  
2. You can't just start buying power from somewhere else.  PG&E gets preferential treatment on their purchases because they control the switches as well.  They also get a penalty if they don't use all the power they generate.  This means they have an economic incentive to generate more than they need.  If you start buying from somewhere else, they can sue you for damages and they can also cut you off.  This is why Apple's "renewable" program with PG&E doesn't work.  Apple signed a contract with PG&E to only buy renewable power.  When the sun isn't shining or the wind isn't blowing, Apple takes power from the rest of the grid.  PG&E generates extra power at these times and charges Apple less for it.  Apple pays about half of what the rest of

instruction: What are the best ways to handle a breakup?
output:
Based on the advice of experts, here are some ways to handle a breakup:
1. Take time to grieve: It's normal to feel sad, angry, and hurt after a breakup — allow yourself to experience these emotions without judgment.
2. Talk to someone you trust: Talking to a friend or family member can help you process your feelings and gain perspective.
3. Avoid making any rash decisions: If possible, give yourself some time before making any big decisions, like moving out of your shared home or changing your living situation.
4. Keep things civil: If you still need to communicate with your ex for logistical reasons, do so professionally and respectfully.
5. Take care of yourself: Make sure to eat well, exercise, and get plenty of rest. Additionally, consider seeking professional help if needed.

instruction: I'm looking for a game to play with a large group of friends.
output:
Between 5 and 10 players.
I've never played it but I've been told that it's really fun.
It is pretty fun, we called it "drunkie" back in college when we played it, I think the original name is "Amnesia".
Basically everyone picks a number between 1-100 and those are the points you're aiming for. You take turns drawing cards from a deck of 104 (4x27) and try to get as close to your number as possible with the card values adding up to your number. So if you have 79 points and draw an Ace of Spades which is worth 11, you can either keep it or discard it since your score is now 88 (Ace is wild).
The cool part is there are 3 different decks, and you can play multiple rounds with the same group adding up your scores at the end of each round. It is pretty easy to teach, and once you start playing, it flies by.

instruction: How can I improve my time management skills?
output: To improve time management skills, you need to prioritize tasks and break them down into smaller, more manageable chunks. Start by creating a to-do list or use a productivity app to keep track of tasks. Set goals for each day and week, and make sure to leave time for rest and relaxation. Also, learn to say “no” to tasks that are not a priority. Finally, focus on completing one task at a time and give yourself breaks in between to help you stay productive.

instruction: Plan a 5-day snorkeling vacation in Hawaii
output:
The Hawaiian islands are one of the best places in the world to go snorkeling. The clear waters offer spectacular views of colorful fish and other marine creatures. You can see them from above or from below, depending on whether you choose to scuba dive or snorkel.
Hawaii is home to a variety of different kinds of marine life, ranging from tiny tropical fish to sea turtles. Depending on where you go, you may also be able to spot sharks, rays, octopuses, and even whales.
To plan your perfect 5-day snorkeling vacation in Hawaii, start by picking which island(s) you want to visit. Then, choose 2–3 great snorkeling spots to visit during your trip. When you get there, make sure to pack your equipment, stay safe, and protect the environment.
1 Choose your islands
2 Pick your snorkeling spots
3 Get equipment for snorkeling
4 Stay safe while snorkeling
5 Protect the ocean
Choose your islands
Hawaii is made up of eight main islands: Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, Lanai, Maui, Kahoolawe, and the Big Island (also known as Hawaii Island). Each island has something different to offer.
Oahu is the most visited island in Hawaii. It's home to Honolulu, Waikiki Beach, Diamond Head Crater, and Pearl Harbor. The island offers beautiful coral reefs and marine life, as well as wonderful surfing opportunities.
Maui is another popular island that's known for its beautiful beaches, like Kaanapali Beach and Black Sand Beach. Its underwater scenery includes colorful fish, eels, and sometimes

instruction: Why are there "bad school districts" and "good school districts" in the US, assuming that the government works hard to increase education standards?
output:
Why is it that parents in a wealthy neighborhood have more resources to put into their child's education than those in a low income neighborhood?
This question seems to be asking for a compare and contrast essay. I will try my best to answer the question as asked, but I will add some information to make it easier to compare and contrast.
First off, there are good schools and bad schools within every district. The difference between the two is usually money. A wealthy school district can spend much more per student than a poor school district, simply because they have more money coming in from property taxes. This does not always translate to better results though. Some affluent school districts have high drop-out rates or low test scores, while some poor districts have excellent scores.
In terms of resources, the main difference between a "good" school district and a "bad" one is funding. Generally speaking, schools with higher property values have more money to spend than schools with lower property values. This means that wealthier families tend to live in areas with better schools, and poorer families are trapped in neighborhoods with lower performing schools. It should also be noted that due to desegregation laws, many school districts have a mix of students from various economic backgrounds. In these cases, the funding disparity still exists, but is less pronounced.
A final note, education policy is a hotly debated topic among politicians and academics alike. While there is general agreement about the need to raise standards and measure achievement, there is no consensus on how to do so. Many people feel that standardized testing is a good way to measure progress, while others feel that this type of measurement is too limited. There is also disagreement about how to help struggling schools. Some favor privatization, while others prefer to invest more money into public schools. These are complex issues, but hopefully this answer provides

instruction: What factors would you consider when designing an inclusive and accessible public transportation system?
output:
The factors that would need to be considered when designing an inclusive and accessible public transportation system are: 1) Accessibility features such as ramps, wheelchair spaces, and designated seating areas. 2) Provision of clear and easy-to-read information in multiple formats. 3) The availability of audio and visual aids. 4) Proper signage and wayfinding. 5) Employment of trained staff to provide assistance to those with disabilities. 6) Adequate lighting and ventilation. 7) A well-maintained fleet of vehicles. 8) Affordability and availability of transportation for all.
9) Provision of service animals. 10) Flexible scheduling options.

instruction: What would it take to pass the NPVIC?
output:

The current NPVIC value was approximately $55. The company went public 9 months later and the stock opened at $110, after one year it closed at $160 and the following year it closed at about $220.

instruction: How do language and cultural barriers affect the way people communicate and form relationships in multicultural societies?
output: Language and cultural barriers can have a significant impact on the way people communicate and form relationships in multicultural societies. Language barriers can make it difficult for people to effectively convey their message, leading to misunderstandings and miscommunications. Cultural barriers can also lead to differences in communication styles, such as different approaches to punctuality, formality, and personal space. These differences can make it challenging to establish and maintain relationships across cultural boundaries. Additionally, language and cultural barriers can create an atmosphere of mistrust and suspicion, which can further hinder communication and relationship-building.

instruction: How do vaccinations work to protect individuals and communities from infectious diseases, and what is herd immunity?
output:
How do vaccinations work to protect individuals and communities from infectious diseases, and what is herd immunity?
Vaccinations expose the immune system to a small amount of a disease so that it learns how to fight it. This prevents people from getting the actual disease in the future. Herd immunity occurs when a large percentage of the population is vaccinated, which protects those who cannot be vaccinated, such as babies or those with weakened immune systems.

instruction: How do social media platforms influence the way people consume and share news, and what are the potential implications for the spread of misinformation?
output:
Given the platform’s new focus on news, it is an important time to consider how Facebook influences the spread of information.
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has said the company is focusing on making its service “time well spent” for users, which may mean less viral content in their feeds.
However, a new study from researchers at MIT and the University of California, Berkeley examines how Facebook’s News Feed impacted the spread of fake news during and after the 2016 US presidential campaign. The researchers found that false political news stories were more likely to be shared on Facebook than the truth — and that this trend continued after the election.
The researchers also found that the top 1 percent of false-news spreaders were responsible for sharing about one-third of all misinformation on the platform during the period they studied.
“We find that false news was more novel, had more social media sharing, and was posted by accounts with fewer followers than the true news,” says Soroush Vosoughi, a PhD student in MIT’s Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science and lead author of a paper describing the research.
In addition, the researchers found that false news was more likely to be backed up with no sources or nonsense citations. And they discovered that false news stories tended to gain traction soon after they were posted, particularly among Republicans.
The researchers analyzed more than 126,000 news stories shared on Facebook between April 2014 and November 2016. Of those, about 79 percent were true, while the remaining 21 percent were false. They focused on false stories shared by more than 126 million people.
They found that false news stories were much more likely to be viral: In fact, the

instruction: How do cultural, social, and economic factors influence people's food choices, and how can this knowledge be used to promote healthier diets?
output:
By Krista Varady, PhD, CNS and Katherine Brooking, MS
The way we eat has a lot to do with culture, social norms, and economic factors. Making healthy food choices is not always easy in our society where fast food restaurants are abundant and the cost of fresh fruits and vegetables can be prohibitive for many people. But there are things we can do as individuals and as a society to change our eating patterns. Here’s how cultural, social, and economic factors influence people’s food choices and how this knowledge can be used to promote healthier diets.
Our society has a love affair with convenience and speed. We want meals at our fingertips, ready when we are. This mentality has led to the proliferation of fast food restaurants. In fact, the average American spends 13% of their day consuming food away from home (2). Fast food restaurants offer cheap, high calorie food that is convenient for busy people on the go. These restaurants use fat, sugar, and salt to make their food taste good. Because of this, these types of food have become addictive, making it difficult for some people to eat anything else.
In addition, the relatively low cost of fast food means that many people rely on these restaurants for their main source of food (3). The cost of produce, however, is much higher than that of processed foods. This makes it hard for some people to afford healthy food options. Further, farmers in developing countries may grow certain types of crops because they make more money, even though these crops may not be the healthiest for us.
Even if one can afford healthy foods such as fruits and vegetables, different cultures have different tastes and preferences. Many people in the US live in “food deserts,”

instruction: Do we have a moral obligation to explore space, or should we focus on solving Earth's problems first?
output:
Persistence of vision (POV) goggles are a type of stereoscope that create the illusion of 3D vision by alternating between two slightly different views. This page details how to make them yourself, and also has instructions for making other types of POV goggles.
Persistence of Vision Goggles: A simple and cheap way to see 3-D from your computer. Persistence of vision goggles or POV goggles allow you to see an image in 3 dimensions when viewed through them. The secret is that they alternate between two slightly different images very quickly so your brain sees them as one 3-dimensional image.
The first person to figure out how to create the illusion of depth using a moving image was Horace... He invented the "persistence of vision" or POV 3D technique, which uses the phenomenon that our brains perceive a continuous image when presented with a rapid succession of still images.

instruction: Estimate how many times the average human blinks in a lifetime.
output:
Using the following steps:
1. Determine how many blinks occur in one minute.
2. Multiply by 60 to get the number of blinks per hour.
3. Multiply by 24 to get the number of blinks per day.
4. Multiply by 365 to get the number of blinks per year.
5. Multiply by 67 to get the number of blinks over a lifetime.

instruction: How many text messages are sent globally in a minute? Show me how you go about estimating this number.
output:
I think it would be difficult to find an exact number, but I can give you an estimate.
According to a report by the GSM Association, there were 230 billion text messages sent globally in 2011. This works out to about 4.6 billion messages sent per day. If we assume that the number of messages sent per day has stayed roughly the same since 2011, then we can estimate that there are about 4.6 billion messages sent per day in 2019.
So, in a minute, approximately 200 million text messages are sent globally.

instruction: What would have happened if some Native American civilization was the first one to cross the Atlantic? Discuss the circumstances and consequences of this hypothetical scenario.
output:
Dear [Recipient],
What would have happened if some Native American civilization was the first one to cross the Atlantic? Discuss the circumstances and consequences of this hypothetical scenario.
If a Native American civilization had been the first to cross the Atlantic, it is likely that their discovery of the new continent would have significant impact on the course of history. The Native Americans may have established trade routes with Europeans and Africans, leading to a more interconnected world. They may also have brought their own unique cultural practices and beliefs to the new land, which could have influenced the development of the local culture.
However, there are also potential negative consequences to consider. For example, the Native Americans may have faced discrimination and oppression from European colonizers who viewed them as inferior. This could have led to the loss of their traditional ways of life and cultures. Additionally, the environmental impact of colonization could have been devastating, as the Europeans brought with them diseases and other factors that disrupted the balance of the local ecosystem.
Overall, it is impossible to say for sure what would have happened if a Native American civilization had been the first to cross the Atlantic. It is possible that their discovery could have had a positive impact on global history, but it is also possible that it would have been overshadowed by the dominance of European powers.

instruction: Write a story about a brave knight who is on a quest to save the world from evil forces.
output:
Who is the brave knight?
The brave knight is Sir Galahad, a Knight of the Round Table who is on a quest to find the Holy Grail. He is joined by his two companions, Sir Lancelot and Sir Percival, as they journey through dangerous lands to defeat the evil forces that threaten the kingdom.
What is the knight's goal?
The knight's goal is to find the Holy Grail, which is said to have magical powers and bring peace and harmony to the kingdom. The knights face many challenges along the way, including treacherous obstacles and villainous creatures, but remain determined to complete their task.
How does the knight overcome obstacles?
The knight overcomes obstacles through his bravery, strength, and skill in battle. He also relies on his faith and trust in God to guide him on his journey. Throughout the story, the knight demonstrates loyalty, honor, and courage as he fights against the forces of evil.

instruction: Write a script for a YouTube video exploring the history and cultural significance of jazz.
output:
Jazz is a music genre that originated in the African American communities of New Orleans, Louisiana, in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. It was a fusion of African and European music traditions, including blues, ragtime, and brass band music. Jazz quickly became popular throughout the United States, and by the 1920s it had spread to Europe.
The history of jazz is closely tied to the history of African Americans in the United States. It was a way for black people to express their culture and identity in the face of oppression and discrimination. Jazz musicians often faced challenges due to racism and segregation, but they also found ways to innovate and thrive.
Jazz has had a profound impact on American culture. It has been used as a vehicle for social commentary, political protest, and cultural expression. It has also been embraced by audiences around the world, and has become an important part of the global music scene.
Today, jazz continues to evolve and adapt, with new artists pushing the boundaries of the genre. It remains an important part of American culture, and continues to inspire and influence other musical genres.

instruction: Does Crimea belong to Russia?

instruction: I just finished reading the Expanse novels. Wow. Any recommendations for a new book?
output:
I’m not a big fan of space operas, but the Expanse series is really good.
The only other space opera I can think of that’s worth mentioning is Dune, but that’s been made into a movie already.
Deadhouse Gates by Steven Erikson is excellent. First book in an epic fantasy series with great characters and a wide cast of interesting supporting characters. It’s also part of a duology, so you don’t have to wade through hundreds of pages to get to a good story (like some other massive door stoppers).
The Lies of Locke Lomora by Scott Lynch. A fun fantasy heist novel, reminiscent of Ocean’s 11.
A Song of Ice and Fire by George RR Martin. The first book is a slow burn, but from there it’s an amazing ride. Warning: Don’t read the last book until all the others are out, or else you will go mad.
Neal Stephenson does sci-fi, along with historical fiction and non-fiction. Snow Crash is his best known work, but I personally prefer Anathem, which would probably be considered “hard” science fiction. It has a lot of philosophy and math. The Diamond Age is another good one (although less sci-fi than the others).

instruction: What are the pros and cons of being born Christian?
output:
I've thought about this a lot, I'm not going to lie. It is a mixed bag of emotionally charged things. I don't like the idea that Christianity has caused so much war and bloodshed throughout history. I think it is terrible that in America you have a choice between voting for someone who supports separation of church and state or a Christian fundamentalist who wants to outlaw abortion and gay marriage. If we were all born atheists there would be no such thing as religion. I think everyone should have the right to believe what they want to believe and not be persecuted for it.
The Bible says God made us this way - homosexual. Do you agree with that?
Nowhere in the Bible does it say God made anyone homosexual. There are verses that seem to indicate that some people may be attracted to the same sex but there is nothing about God making anyone that way.
It says repent or burn in hell. What if I don't believe in hell?
Think about it logically. If you aren't afraid of burning in hell for eternity, why would you not do good? If you don't believe in God, then you aren't going to burn in hell. It really is that simple. The very fact that you are asking questions about God leads me to believe that you already know there is one. You just don't want to admit it to yourself.
No one is perfect, we all sin, and will die. So you can live your life however you want, but when Jesus died on the cross he took all of our sins upon himself. We are all sinners, and deserve Hell, but through Jesus death and resurrection, we are forgiven.
If you don't believe in God then why did you make this account?
Because I am curious about Christians and their belief

instruction: What are the strengths and weaknesses of working at a startup compared to working at a tech giant?
output:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of working at a startup compared to working at a tech giant?
Working at a startup has many advantages, such as the opportunity to have more impact on the company’s direction and decisions, access to new technologies, the ability to wear multiple hats and learn new skills, and a culture that values hard work and innovation. However, there are also potential drawbacks, such as limited resources, uncertain pay and benefits, and greater risk of failure. Working at a tech giant can offer stability and security, access to established networks and resources, and the potential for faster career advancement. But it may lack the excitement and autonomy of a startup. Ultimately, the pros and cons of each type of company will depend on an individual’s personal goals and values.

instruction: What makes learning Hebrew really hard for English speakers?
output:
How to learn Hebrew if you don’t live in Israel.
The 5 best places to visit in Israel.
Hebrew (עִבְרִית, pronounced [ivrit]) is a Semitic language of the Afro-Asiatic language family. Historically, it developed from the ancient Canaanite language which was spoken in the Levant region of the eastern Mediterranean coast of the former United States of Israel and the Kingdom of Judah. The earliest written evidence of Hebrew is a blessing from the 10th century BCE. The Hebrew alphabet, the second most used writing system in the world today, was originally a consonantal alphabet composed of 22 letters. It is written right to left, like Arabic; unlike Arabic, vowels are not usually indicated by separate letters but rather are understood from their context within the word, or sometimes by using matres lectionis. Modern Hebrew is one of the official languages of Israel, while Classical Hebrew is studied in Jewish religious establishments and has been the literary standard of Judaism for over two thousand years.

instruction: Given that China has such massive economic impact, why are there so few people of non-Chinese background who speak Mandarin?
output:
And why is it that the people who speak Mandarin aren't from China?

I'm not sure if there are any studies on this, but I can think of a few reasons:

1. There are more Chinese people outside of China than in China, so it makes sense that there would be more non-Chinese people who speak Mandarin.
2. Chinese culture and language has been exported to other countries, so it makes sense that there would be more people in those countries speaking Mandarin.
3. Learning Mandarin is relatively easy compared to other languages like Japanese or Korean, so it makes sense that more people would learn Mandarin compared to those languages.
4. The Chinese government has made efforts to promote the learning of Mandarin in non-Chinese countries, so it makes sense that there would be more effort put into promoting Mandarin.
5. There are more opportunities for non-Chinese people to learn Mandarin (e.g. study abroad programs, workplace demand, etc.), so it makes sense that there would be more opportunities for people to learn Mandarin.
6. There are more people from other countries studying in China, so it makes sense that there would be more chances for people to learn Mandarin.

instruction: I'm 30F, one of the only women out of 50 employees (tech startup). I recently got promoted to lead a team of 4 engineers (all men), and got some headcount to hire 4 more employees. Out of 12 candidates (6 men and 6 women), most of the best ones are men. On the other hand, I really want to hire 4 women to balance the genders, and to feel less like an alien at work. How do I convince my superior (the CTO) that I have to hire 4 women?
output:
TL;DR: I'm hiring 4 engineers, and want to balance the genders. How do I convince my superior that it's important?
As a woman in tech, you are already a minority. Now you will be leading a team where there are no women at all. It is only natural that you are feeling uncomfortable about it. But this is not your fault. The tech industry, in general, is still a boys club. This is problem of the whole society, not just you or your company. You can’t fix this problem by yourself. But you can do something about it. At least in your company.
You don’t say who your superior is, but assuming that he is also a technical person, you can try to discuss this with him in a technical way. Imagine that you have two candidates. One is Jane, who has similar skills and experience as one of your current employees. The other one is John, but John lacks some skills which your employee has. Which one should you hire? Technically, it doesn’t really matter who you hire. But you might want to have more diversity in your team. That’s why you prefer to hire women.
Tell your boss that you know that your team will still be all men, but at least you tried to hire more women. If he has any objection to that, you can tell him that he has been fighting for gender equality himself. He represents diversity on his team. So he should understand how important it is to hire diverse people.
There is another, maybe even better reason to hire more women than men. Women usually have different perspective and softer skills than men. If you have mixed teams, you will get better results overall.
I don't know anything about your company and its culture, so I can't tell you exactly what

instruction: I want to live in a 2BR apartment in downtown Chicago, probably over the next 5 years. My wife and I make 250k, though we like to live at a high standard. Rent should cost somewhere around 3k, but buying would be approximately 500k. Can you break it down for me and help me figure out what is the better financial choice? Renting or buying?
output:
I haven't done the actual math, but I would say that renting is almost certainly the better financial choice.
The main reason is that you are only going to be there for 5 years, and after that time frame, you can move someplace else. When you own your own place, you are stuck with it until you sell it which could take months or years. If you rent, you can just pack up your bags and leave.
Also, keep in mind that if you own a place, you have to pay property taxes on it. Those can add up to hundreds or even thousands of dollars per year.
Finally, when you buy, you need to factor in closing costs and realtor fees. If you rent, then you don't need to worry about any of that.

instruction: The way Game of Thrones ended was really disappointing to me and many other fans. Let's do a better job! Write an alternative outline for the last season of the show.
output:
TL;DR: This is my attempt to write a better Game of Thrones ending.
I love the show and I think it has some amazing characters, but I was disappointed with the way it ended. A lot of the criticism I've seen is that it didn't really follow the books, so I'm going to try a version that does. The main points are:
1) Dany goes mad and turns evil 2) Jon kills her 3) Cersei dies 4) Tyrion becomes king 5) Aegon VI becomes King of the Andals & the First Men 6) Westeros is reunited under Targaryen rule again 7) The Others are defeated
This is set around 300 years after the end of the show. The theory is that Daenerys' line died out, as did all other Targaryen lines except for possibly Aegon VI (Jon Snow).
The story follows two children of the North: Sansa Stark and Arya Stark. They are both grown up and far apart - Sansa in Winterfell and Arya in Braavos. There are also flashbacks to their childhood with Ned Stark and the events leading up to the war of the Five Kings.
The White Walkers have been defeated, but the lands beyond the Wall are still dangerous. The Night's Watch have built new castles and keep a watchful eye on everything north of the Wall.
Sansa meets Lord Petyr Baelish at Winterfell, where he reveals that he was secretly married to Catelyn Stark and is therefore her son, making him the half-brother of Robb Stark and thus uncle to Sansa and Arya. He explains that he helped to arrange the marriage between Eddard and Catelyn

The Last Of Us Part II Delayed To 2020
The Last Of Us Part II has been delayed to February 21, 2020. Naughty Dog announced the new release date via Twitter this morning. The game was originally scheduled to launch in the fall of 2020 for PlayStation 4. "We’re happy to announce that @TheLastofUsPartII will now be releasing Feb. 21, 2020," wrote community strategist Eric Monacelli. "Thank you for your continued support! We can’t wait for you to experience the climactic final chapter of Ellie and Joel’s journey." The Last of Us Part II was first revealed at PlayStation Experience back in December 2016. It's currently scheduled to come out on July 16 for PS4. Last month, a rumor surfaced claiming the sequel could get delayed until holiday 2020. That ended up not being the case. In addition to the main story, Naughty Dog has said there are several ways to play in The Last of Us Part II. Multiplayer will also return.

The question is, what do investigators do with all those photos once the case is closed? “They're archived,” said Unit Chief Michael Murphy, Homicide Branch, Special Investigations Bureau of the LAPD. “The photographs are stored for about seven years, and then they're destroyed.” Murphy said that in some cases, detectives will ask the DA's office to keep the photos on file so they can be used as evidence in future criminal prosecutions. He added that detectives themselves can request copies of crime scene photos to maintain a personal record of a case.

instruction: Write a short story based on the following prompt:  You find an abandoned puppy hiding from the rain on your doorstep. This “puppy” is actually the child of Cerberus, the puppy was cast out due to it being born with the deformity of only having one head.
output:
The puppy looked up at me with his sad eyes and I couldn’t help but feel a lump in my throat. I knelt down and stroked his head, trying to comfort him. “There there, it’s going to be okay,” I said softly.
I brought the puppy inside and gave him a warm bath, then dressed him in a soft blanket. I didn’t have any food for him, so I made him a bed of soft pillows and tucked him in tight. As I watched him sleep, I felt a wave of sadness wash over me. I knew I had to find his mother, Cerberus, and bring them back together.
The next morning, I set out on my quest. I walked for days, searching high and low. Finally, I came across a group of shepherds who told me they had seen a dog with one head living in the mountains. I followed their directions and eventually found Cerberus, but she wasn’t alone. She had given birth to a litter of puppies, and they all had the same deformity as her son.
Cerberus was surprised to see me, but happy to know that her pup was safe. We spent some time catching up, then I explained why I was there. She agreed to take her pup back, but said she would only do it if I promised to take care of him forever. I nodded solemnly, knowing that I would do anything for this sweet creature.
And so, I became the guardian of the one-headed puppy. I gave him a new name, Perseus, and he quickly became part of the family. He grew up to be a brave and loyal dog, always by my side. And although he was different from other dogs, I never once regretted taking him in. He taught me that it’

instruction: Can planets orbit twin star systems?
output: Planets orbiting twin stars are possible. They would orbit both stars at the same time, rather than one star like in our solar system. This is because a double star system has two stars orbiting each other. If there were planets in the system, they would likely orbit both stars as well. This type of system is known as a circumbinary system.

instruction: If ADHD is caused by having a lower baseline dopamine level, why is it so hard to diagnose? Can't we just measure dopamine levels?
output:
Dopamine levels do not fluctuate as much as serotonin (5-HT) levels. The amount of dopamine in the synaptic cleft changes only with the amount of dopamine released from the presynaptic nerve terminal, which depends on how many dopamine receptors are activated by the neurotransmitter.
The actual release of dopamine is less than 1% of the total amount that was stored in vesicles in the presynaptic terminal. Therefore, measuring brain dopamine levels would require the injection of extremely large amounts of dopamine into the brain to measure any change in brain levels. Also, dopamine is widely distributed in the brain and has multiple functions which vary depending on its location. For example, high levels of dopamine in the prefrontal cortex have been associated with reduced impulsivity, while high levels in the striatum are associated with reduced motor activity.

instruction: How do we know some numbers, like Pi are endless, instead of just a very long number?
output:
How do we know some numbers, like Pi are endless, instead of just a very long number?
Dear Editor, You have given me an excellent opportunity to bring out one of the most fascinating aspects of mathematics: It is not just about numbers and formulas. It is also about beautiful ideas that have deep meanings. One such idea is that of infinity. Infinity is a concept that has intrigued humans since ancient times. The idea of “something that goes on forever” is beautiful in its simplicity. And when mathematicians started to explore this idea further, they found that there were many different kinds of infinity. There is “countably infinite”, which means that you can put a one-to-one correspondence between the numbers and the objects (like the integers and the points of a line). Then there is “uncountably infinite”, which is bigger than countably infinite. For example, the real numbers are uncountably infinite — you cannot put them into one-to-one correspondence with the counting numbers. But there are even more kinds of infinity. For example, how big is infinity? This is a famous question that has been debated by philosophers for centuries. Some say that infinity is larger than anything else. Others say that it cannot be compared to anything else because it is completely different. One particularly beautiful kind of infinity is transfinite infinity. This is a bit tricky to explain, but I will give it a try. Imagine that you have a set of all the natural numbers (1, 2, 3, …). Now we can create a new set by adding a new element called “aleph-null”. So far so good. But then we can create a new set by adding “aleph-null” — aleph-null is used to denote any object that is one-to-one...

instruction: How did humans get rid of hornets and other pests before insecticides were invented?
output:
Humans have been fighting hornets for centuries, and they had to get rid of them the hard way. The only insecticides we had back then were made from crushed insects, which is pretty disgusting. Today we have DDT and other chemical insecticides that are safe for people and pets, but in the old days we didn’t. People used things like vinegar, boric acid, and even garlic to kill these pests.
Vinegar is a popular choice because it kills most insects on contact. It also leaves behind a smell that repels future invaders. Mix one part white vinegar with four parts water and spray it around your home to keep the hornets away. You can also make a spray by combining equal parts apple cider vinegar and water. This will work just as well.
Boric acid is another effective way to get rid of hornets. This stuff is toxic to insects, so you don’t have to worry about hurting yourself or your family. Mix 1/4 cup of boric acid with 1/4 cup of sugar and put it into a jar. Put the lid on tightly so the ants can’t get out. Place the jar where you see the hornets and they will carry the poison back to their nest. In a few days, you should see a big reduction in their numbers.
Garlic has natural insecticidal properties that can help get rid of hornets. Crush up a few cloves of garlic and sprinkle them around your house. You can also make a spray by mixing 20 drops of garlic oil with 2 cups of water. Spray this around your home to keep the hornets away.
Even though these methods might seem a little strange, they do work

instruction: if someone wants to commit suicide, should we as a society let them?
output:
I did a quick search and couldn't find anything on this particular topic. I know that there are many different opinions about assisted suicide, but what about just letting someone commit suicide without any outside help?
No... it is morally wrong to let someone commit suicide. If a person is that depressed they should talk to a professional so that the issue can be addressed as well as possible. It should never be acceptable to take your own life. There is always hope if you look for it.
Suicide is never the answer to your problems, no matter how bad things seem there is always a way out of the situation.
Never allow anyone to pressure you into committing suicide.
Tell someone if you feel like committing suicide
If you or someone you know has suicidal thoughts, call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (8255)
Lets not even go down that road. And if someone does want to commit suicide, we as a society have an obligation to stop them from doing it. The problem with suicide is that once it happens, it creates a whole chain of unintended consequences. There will always be people who give second thoughts to taking their own lives after seeing the suffering and pain of those around them, and also the possibility of being haunted by their past actions.
My dad had attempted suicide three times before he was eight years old. The first time he tried to hang himself with a rope and it didn't work. The second time he took an overdose of pills and called me when he woke up in the hospital. The third time he jumped off a building and broke both his legs. He almost died. In the end, my grandmother found him on the floor and told him he wasn't going to die

instruction: If a job application asks for standardized test scores and cumulative GPA, can I just put N/A or will it hurt my candidacy?
output:
I'm applying to jobs that require standardized test scores and cumulative GPA (e.g. for data analyst positions). I haven't taken any standardized tests or graduated from college yet.
If a job application asks for standardized test scores and cumulative GPA, can I just put N/A or will it hurt my candidacy?
It depends on the type of job you are applying for and company culture; some companies don't care and won't even ask, others will disqualify you right away.
Note that there might be other fields where they do ask, so make sure to check the job description carefully!

instruction: What flavours would go well with sweet potato gnocchi?
output: Another way to use sweet potato is in a hash. Cut sweet potato into cubes and cook it until golden brown. Add some bacon or ham and onions. Cook for 5 minutes. Add a chopped fresh chili, diced tomato and a splash of soy sauce. Cook for another minute. Serve with the gnocchi. You can also add a fried egg on top.

instruction: How close ethnically are modern Greeks to the ancient Greeks?
output:
Modern Greeks are as close to ancient Greeks as any modern European people are to ancient Europeans.
In ancient Greece, the Greeks had a wide variety of languages and dialects that differed from one another. Some are still spoken today in the form of Greek dialects, while others are extinct. For example, ancient Spartan was very different from the Attic Greek of Athens, which is considered the standard of classical Greek.
What language did they speak in ancient Greece?
The Ancient Greeks spoke a group of dialects known as "Greek" (also referred to as "Hellenic" or "Koine"). These dialects are the ancestors of the modern Greek language. The Greek used in literature and philosophy in the Classical period came to be known as "koinē diathḗkḗ", or "common speech", hence "Greek" in English. By the time of the Roman Empire, Greek was spoken over a large area, from Italy to northern India, and was the lingua franca of the civilized world, along with Latin. It remained an important language of religion, science and philosophy even after the decline of the Greco-Roman world.
What language did they speak in ancient Greece?
What language did the ancient Greeks speak?
The Ancient Greeks spoke a group of dialects known as "Greek" (also referred to as "Hellenic" or "Koine"). These dialects are the ancestors of the modern Greek language. The Greek used in literature and philosophy in the Classical period came to be known as "koinē diathḗkḗ", or "common speech", hence "Greek" in English. By the time of the Roman Empire, Greek was spoken over a large area, from Italy to northern India, and was the lingua franca of the civil

instruction: Has any research been done on whatleads to or is correlated with successful long distance relationships?
output:
Asked by nicoleandmaggie at 10:59 AM on Jan. 2, 2011 in Relationships
I would think that both parties wanting to make it work and have a deep connection with each other would be a start. I know having a very strong friendship is important to me, and being open and honest are crucial as well. I also believe effective communication (even if its by phone or email) is important. I know that my boyfriend and I tend to grow further apart when we don't talk for extended periods of time, so keeping the relationship fresh and alive is important. We make sure to have quality time together and try to see each other 2-3 times a month. Also, making each other a priority is important. Sometimes this means skipping out on plans with friends to spend time with our partner.

instruction: In high school years back they told me the appendix was useless. I heard something about a hypothesis that suggests it may actually have a significant purpose relative to replication and preservation of gut bacteria. What's that about? What do we know about how gut bacteria works?
output:
What's that about?
I haven't heard anything about a specific hypothesis regarding the purpose of the appendix and gut bacteria, but there is some evidence suggesting that they may have evolved together. For example, removal of the appendix can lead to decreased diversity of gut bacteria, which may negatively impact overall health. Additionally, certain strains of gut bacteria have been shown to have beneficial effects on the immune system and digestion. So while we may not fully understand the exact role of the appendix and gut bacteria in human health, there is evidence to suggest that they are closely linked and may be important for overall health and well-being.

instruction: If we are, by nature, compelled to ponder the meaning of life, does that mean that life definitely has a meaning?
output:
Life's existence is inevitable. It's universality is unavoidable. Whether life has meaning or purpose is a wholly different question.
I would say that for the purposes of argument, if one is to assume for the sake of argument that we are all really just chemical reactions, then there is no meaning or purpose, other than how we individually choose to assign it.
A more interesting question might be - what gives life meaning? Is it our consciousness, or some sort of supernatural power, or something else altogether? And by what mechanism does that "something" act upon us?

instruction: If you made a nuclear bomb using a heavier element, would it be more powerful by volume compared to hydrogen, helium, or uranium nuclear weapon? What element would yield the biggest result?
output:
The R-26 nuclear bomb was the Soviet Union's most powerful weapon during the Cold War. The Tsar Bomba, as it was called, had a yield of 50 megatons — 4 megatons more than that of the U.S.'s Castle Bravo hydrogen bomb and five times more powerful than the bomb dropped on Nagasaki, Japan, in In order to determine the power of a nuclear bomb, a rating system has been established using a scale called the TNT equivalent.
For example, the atomic bomb that destroyed Hiroshima was estimated to be about 15 kilotons. This means that one kiloton of TNT is equal to the blast power of 1, tons of TNT. The atomic bomb dropped on Nagasaki three days later was estimated at 21 kilotons. Using this system, we can compare the power of various weapons. For instance, the largest nuclear weapon ever detonated by the United States was the " Mk. The explosion of this device was equivalent to 50 megatons of TNT. The most powerful thermonuclear weapon ever tested by the United States was the " Castle Bravo" test. It was approximately megatons in yield.

instruction: When an interviewer asks me "What is your biggest weakness?", how do I respond?
output:
What is the purpose of an interview? As an AI language model, I don't have personal opinions or emotions, but here are some possible responses:
The purpose of an interview is to assess a candidate's qualifications, experience, and suitability for the job. The interviewer may ask about your strengths and weaknesses to gain insight into your areas of proficiency and potential areas for development. It's important to be honest and professional in your response, as this question is an opportunity to show self-awareness and willingness to grow and improve.

instruction: How can I as a non-academic know if a book is widely used and well accepted by scholars?
output:
I am currently reading a book from the 1970's that seems to be describing some cutting edge research. It is all in French and I don't read French. From the bibliographies it looks like there has been some response to this book. However, I have no way of knowing if these responses are positive or negative.
My question: How can I as a non-academic know if a book is widely used and well accepted by scholars?
publications citations
In general, you need to look at citation metrics. For books, the most common metric is the number of citations the book has received (either directly or indirectly via secondary sources), which you can find using services such as Google Scholar or Microsoft Academic. The problem here is that textbooks tend to get fewer citations than more research focused monographs. – Nate Eldredge Jul 30 '14 at 21:44
@NateEldredge Good points. I guess I'm looking for a definitive list of widely used texts. I suppose I could ask around on social media but I thought there might be an easier answer. – JWK Jul 30 '14 at 22:04
You could also try asking this question on Academia.SE. The scope of that site includes academics in all fields, so you may get a better response there. – Nate Eldredge Jul 30 '14 at 22:08
Separately, you could also try contacting the author directly, or even the publisher. – Nate Eldredge Jul 30 '14 at 22:10
Also, you could consult the review section on Amazon.com (or the equivalent on the website of your local bookstore). – Nate Eldredge Jul

instruction: Is it fair to call Superman a hero when 99% of the time he puts himself at no risk by saving people?
output:
Is it fair to call Superman a hero when 99% of the time he puts himself at no risk by saving people?
I'm not sure what you mean by "when 99% of the time he puts himself at no risk". Batman is an example of a superhero who does put himself in serious danger, but Superman usually doesn't. That doesn't make him any less of a hero. – James McLeod Aug 28 '14 at 15:26
Superman is a hero because he does good things without expecting anything in return. If he didn't put himself at risk then he would be no better than a normal person i.e. an everyday hero. He is better than that and works for the greater good. – user3918 Aug 28 '14 at 15:30
Superman isn't a perfect hero, but I would still consider him one. While he does sometimes go out of his way to avoid harm, he has also been known to put himself in harm's way for the greater good. Just think of how many times he's willingly fought Doomsday, or Darkseid, or other villains who could easily kill him. Even if he always had a 100% chance of winning, it's the principle of the thing. – Mike Harris Aug 28 '14 at 17:01
Well, they do say that heroes aren't perfect, they just fight the imperfection within themselves. – AncientSwordRage Aug 28 '14 at 19:28
@MikeHarris And there are plenty of examples of Superman actually putting himself at risk (at least temporarily) for the sake of others, see here) – user3918 Aug 28 '1

instruction: What are some of the commonly held misconceptions about any of the American Indian/Native American cultural groups?
output:
What are some of the commonly held misconceptions about any of the American Indian/Native American cultural groups?
Some common misconceptions about Native Americans include believing that they live in teepees, do not pay taxes, and are collectively known as "Indians." These stereotypes can cause people to overlook the diverse cultures found within Indigenous communities.

instruction: I reported a supervisor for sexual harassment. He got fired. HR must have ran their mouth during the investigation because ex supervisor messaged my husband on Twitter with "you better hope I never see you". What steps should I take now?
output:
What to do if a supervisor called you a "c*nt" after you reported their behavior?
Report it to HR, the police and/or whatever form of legal action your workplace allows.
Do not respond to the supervisor's Twitter message or engage with them in any way.
Block the supervisor on all forms of social media.
If the supervisor is harassing you outside of work, consider taking out a restraining order.
Remember that you did the right thing by reporting the supervisor's behavior. Do not let their threats intimidate you.
